comments.commentBody:
Sorry, judge, it is a public relations/customer service failure.

I work for a company in the hospitality industry, and worked before that in consumer product goods. In these companies, customer service is always considered. As a country, we talk incessantly, write books, hire consultants, etc., etc., all in regard to customer service. Yet, for the most part, customer service in this country is abysmal. So, I take this story as an illustration of how we talk endlessly about customer service, yet do not practice what we preach.

Companies, such as MSG, ask feedback because they "value us as customers." What garbage ... this story shows what that is all about, they want positive feedback, and all they value is our money.

P.S. - You might also consider the fact that everything the fan wrote to Dolan IS TRUE!!!

Wow, you missed the point by a country mile. Let's see:

Customer service: Big fail.

Public relations: Big fail.

Corporate management: Big fail.

Insulting your customers - and in a public way using email -- is just incredibly dumb. And when the person making these incredibly dumb comments is at the head of a multimillion-dollar franchise, that becomes news. Big news.

What a country this has become; the "Indignation Nation".  So Dolan writes this guy an email telling him to take a hike...that's news?   There is nothing earth-shaking, or even mildly inappropriate involved.  Just a business owner telling a customer to take his business to another store.  If you're a person who get's your knickers in a twist over that, you need to talk to someone.
Dolan, by his over-the-top response to a man old enough to be his father, shows himself to be, as is said in the trade, a "dry drunk."

It’s no surprise that we are beginning to notice more ads other than what we see on television or billboards. Technology, and the way the method of advertising has been changing say a lot about our culture today. As mentioned in the article, more ads are being produced through social media platforms such as Facebook and I think by doing this, it forces individuals to take notice of them. Even though it may be political or not, this type of advertising in my opinion is a good way to get a message across without having to invest in so much dollars into a campaign. I use Facebook everyday and even if there is something on my feed that I may like, I still see it. Therefore, I think that using this strategy to advertise will not only generate more viewers but also gain more political views.
No mention made of female characters over the age of 50.  That sort of speaks for itself, doesn't it?  (And 90% of them were played by Meryl Streep.)

I am a hospice nurse.  It is not true that hospices "don't like" dementia patients.  It is just that the criteria for allowing them onto their hospice benefit is really very strict. Medicare will charge the hospice with fraud if criteria is not met and documented. It is a shame because most need our services early, yet we cannot allow it. It makes us so angry because we know we can help. And they do not allow home health services easily either. Most do not have skilled needs. It puts the family and patient in peril. It is so frustrating.

I come from a background of Computer Science. Computer Scientists try to find the most efficient way to solve a problem. When a problem is too large, you try to divide it into smaller problems and then try to solve those. You keep dividing until you have a bunch of smaller problems that you can solve.

Solving human problems is challenging in many ways, but can we help some of the mentally ill homeless off the streets, etc. We may not be able to save every homeless person, but we need to be smart, and we need a strategy in how we help. Dollars are not unlimited, so we need to be able to help the most with what we have. In a M.A.S.H. unit they must a triage process. For some homeless perhaps the best we can do is a meal and a cot. But let's see if we can divide the total number of homeless by getting some folks re-integrated back in to life.

Oh let's do continue your list

Take charge of your life and

* do not have schizophrenia develop

* do not have bi-polar illness develop

* do not get MS or cardiac disease (which runs in your family) or another illness or long term injury like spinal degeneration or disc damage

* do not take a job stocking the shelves so I can shop or ringing up my latte or mopping the floors of my office or working as a home health aide for my parents or any one of the other jobs that I expect someone to do to provide me with goods and service which do not pay enough fro you to live indoors

There - fixed it for you

Yeah know back in the 1970s, we use to joke that happiness was ending up in the 50% tax bracket. ANd here you are whining about what you pay in income tax bother federal and state and your real estate taxes on you undoubtedly multi-million dollar co-op or condo and the sales tax on your $800 pair of shoes

Now that is revolting and I have no sympathy for you

PS your taxes are providing things for you - schools, universities, roads, police, fire, clean air and water, disease research .........

If you're feeling sad and lonely, there's a service I can render: play the first movement of Eine Kleine Nachtmusik on repeat. If that doesn't get you out of your funk, time to seek professional help.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tSL5-wxgvFY

Who's getting hurt?

American representative democracy, which is being replaced by oligarchy/plutocracy.

We have too many home-grown oligarchs (Waltons, Kochs,...) as it is. Don't need to import more.

Why would you expect these reporters to "advocate" for anything in particular?  That would belong on the editorial page. Journalism 101.  As for your allegation that these NYT reporters "wallow in innuendo," it's the opacity of these real estate transactions which generates a smokescreen, not the quality of the reporting.  The fact is, rather, that these buyers and the attendant careerists who make money off of them wallow in obscurantism.  The NYT may not have uncovered evidence of money laundering *yet*, but these pieces are a good start.

In the early 2000's , on a flight to JFK, I sat across the aisle from Coach Smith. I respected his privacy, only to ask coach how he was doing as we were preparing to get off the flight.

I took the chance entounter to write Coach Smith a letter about my Adminstrative Assistant (a long time die-hard Tar Heels fan and Coach Smith idolizer) who was in the hospital in terrible condition. In the letter, I mentioned our less than casual meeting and expessed a request about this individual, her condition, and her situation at UNC Hospital. Asking for him to send her a note, providing her name and specific hospital information.

Instead of sending anything to the hospital, Coach Smith sent me a package with an autographed photo with a wonderful personal note to her, and a separate profound personal note to me, asking me to hand deliver it to her, insisting that my gesture must not be unnoticed.

He followed that up with personal visits to see her every time he made his visits to the hospital (which were frequent). The impact was extraordinary on all of us, and a display on the Man that he was. For the patient, it fulfilled a dream of meeting Coach and as she called it "an inspiration to fight on". Eventually she succumbed to her illness, but the compassion Coach Smith provided her, gave her and her family such joy and comfort to her and her family during such trying times. Coach Smith also taught me a lesson as a young executive what class and leadership really are.

I graduated from UNC in '66 when Dean Smith was just getting started and so his accomplishments in later years were something of a surprise to me. I, too, was never a fan of his four corners offense which, if I'm not mistaken, he employed less and less as the talent on his rosters improved. Besides his championships, what stands out in my mind was an interview that he gave many years after retirement when he said the record he was most proud of was the fact that he graduated 97% of his players. How lucky they were to have played for him!

If you really seriously don't know what caused climate change (over tens of thousands of years, not a few decades) in the distant past you shouldn't even be commenting on a climate change thread until you have educated yourself in such basic schoolboy general knowledge. How can you POSSIBLY not know that?
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles
And - for the thousandth time - the LIA (if it can be said to have existed at all) was a regional event not a global event. At most there was modest cooling of the Northern Hemisphere during the period.
This has been known now for over twenty years.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Ice_Age
It would have taken you less than a minute to check that out for yourself.

The average GLOBAL temperature had been very slowly falling since te end of the the Holocence Climatic Optimum over 6,000 years ago until around 1900 when the GLOBAL temperature suddenly spiked, more than undoing the previous 6,000 years of slow cooling.
This has also been known for over twenty years.
It has also been known that a rise in CO2 would cause the Earth to warm since 1896. It has been proved beyond all and any reasonable doubt whatsoever. Stop parroting denialist junk that you don't even understand.
Cosmically, the college basketball game just got a lot more watchable. May Smith's detested 4-corners slowdown offense never come back. Ever.
And the crazy part was how often it didn't really help the sky-blue V-necked five. But, man, he loved to plug it in.

'Fastest growing minority'

Time was when real environmentalists were concerned about population growth.

USE chicken soup, so I'm TOLD. It KOS DAT run down feeling. Or was it an APPLE a day? I think both TYPES of approaches to well being would YIELD a nice warm fuzzy feeling malaise sufferers are seeking. Another alternative, when things are running AMOK, is to TAP a barrel of your favorite ADULT beverage and sip hungrily. A good brandy works wonders on stuffy NASAL passages. AS TO caveats, be careful, whiskey's not for the faint of heart and has been known to SNEAK up on the unsuspecting imbiber...I'm starting to get the hang of these WP POSTS. Solving NYTXWP's? NOT so fast...Today's clip is from a NAT'L treasure, Waylon Jennings. You will all feel better after you hear him sing about the Land of Enchantment which, incidentally, is where the WOMYN half of today's superb tag-team of constructors resides. OLES!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eouQSxzlCmY

SEE YA/ADIEU,

Bru

The joke question went around for decades:
''Who was the last man to hold Michael Jordan under (so many) points? Coach Dean Smith''

I never saw the man have a bad day. As far as the too-easy no-show-up classes go, those things are going to happen and always will. And I never heard of him having cash sent to people for any reason.
In the spring, the Chapel Hill campus was truly beautiful, like a hilly Augusta National GC.
Kind of a contradiction, being allegedly concerned about 'the environment' and then implicitly praising 'hispanics' for basically fueling the US's runaway population growth.

This won't be recalled in the tilted sports media any more, but Adolph Rupp was shocked and disappointed when he first saw how badly black Lexingtonians lived on his first trip to Kentucky with his taking that job.
Exactly. Only on Planet Republican can people "have a position" on the temperature at which water freezes.

"The mountain snowpacks required for both cities and agriculture are dangerously low this winter season both in the Pacific Northwest and the Southwest."

Perhaps if we didn't have a million **legal** immigrants a year, many of who settle in the SW, California, or the Northwest, then pressure on water supplies would be less. After all, Americans have , by their own behavior, shown they want a stable population.

and Elke
John/Martin,
Yesterday we had "Where's Waldo?" Today we have "Why ALTO ?"- a memo written in 1972 which ultimately resulted in us being able to communicate as we are. The PC has made the jobs of most of us much easier. How we got there has left some of us feeling OUT OF SORTS and IN THE DUMPS.
In 1979 we had one of the early STARs occupying the better part of a desk and were IN AWE of the Ethernet which allowed a 30- page manuscript to be sent 500 miles in < 2 minutes. Now I TYPE on a HP Notebook while eating an APPLE , but I don't have an I-Pad or I-phone.
Did you ever think that Hispanics, like other people, may be capable of having 2 or more thoughts in their minds at the same time?
